body:
The 3k requests you received was not likely an attack - it was just a bot scanning your site for known dangerous URLs - this is just normal background noise for any internet facing server.

I can confirm this, it's actually a bug in the JDK, `JarURLInputStream.getInputStream` is returning a `FilterInputStream` that delegates to the underlying input stream for the jar entry, but if that entry is a directory, then that input stream is null.  The JDK should probably be returning null here.  We actually correctly check for null.

We can work around this in Play by calling getJarFile and closing that, though looking at the source code, looks like we should conditionally do that based on whether getUseCaches returns true or not (don't close it if it returns true).
Is there any progress on this issue?

As noted by @jroper the actual problem is in the implementation of `JarURLInputStream` of `sun.net.www.protocol.jar.JarURLConnection`. It is unclear if this problem also occurs on OpenJDK.

How bad would it be to wrap the `close` call at [Assets.scala#L149](https://github.com/playframework/playframework/blob/2.3.x/framework/src/play/src/main/scala/play/api/controllers/Assets.scala#L149) in a try/catch for `NullPointerException`?
Wrapping the close would work - but is not ideal if the other suggestion I made is practical (I don't know if it is or not).

Is it even an option to close the JarFile without closing the InputStream if the latter is not null? I guess not, because the close() method on JarURLInputStream _already_ closes the JarFile after the input stream is closed. That's where the Exception is thrown.

There seems to be no need for the `close` on the `InputStream`. The [commit that introduced this code](https://github.com/playframework/playframework/commit/3b78a4a184dd9904eaabd44426879e39da7b4aff) added the `try-finally` block. The original code:

``` scala
Option(resource.openConnection)     
  .map(_.asInstanceOf[JarURLConnection].getJarEntry.getTime)        
  .filterNot(_ == -1)
```

This implies that the code was not introduced as a bug fix.

On top of that, it does not make sense to `close` an input stream that was never opened. `getJarEntry.getTime` does not open the stream. The effect of the current implementation is that the stream is opened just to close it.

My suggestion would be to remove the `try-finally` block and the call to `close` the stream.

There is absolutely a resource leak in the original code there, if you open a connection to a resource, and that resource is a jar file, a file descriptor is created for accessing the jar.  If you don't close it, you leak a file descriptor.  It may eventually be cleaned up by a finalize method, but we should not rely on that.

Yes, it's the `JarURLConnection` that holds the resource (file descriptor, socket etc) that needs to be closed - this is the case for all `URLConnection`'s.  The `InputStream` you get from it holds no resources, and it costs nothing to get it, but without casting the `URLConnection`, the only way to close a `URLConnection` is to get the input stream and close that, which is why it's done that way currently in the code.  We can (and should) implement the above code for `JarUrlConnection`, but we still need to do the `getInputStream.close` for all other types of url connections (the main other type here would be `FileUrlConnection`, which would be quite common for this code to encounter in dev mode) since we don't want to have to match on every possible type of `URLConnection` that could be returned and implement the method specific to that to close it.

I mentioned the need to check `getUseCaches` in my [original comment](https://github.com/playframework/playframework/issues/3459#issuecomment-57318827).
We're seeing those also on an internet facing server. Any chance for a 2.3.x fix/workaround?

issue.title: Assets controller returns 404 for directories

repository.name: playframework
repository.description: The Community Maintained High Velocity Web Framework For Java and Scala.

issue.body:
This is instead of 200 or 500 (depending on where the directory was found).

Fixes #3459.

body: @jroper @pvlugter Any chance this will be backported to `2.3.x`?
+1, would also like to see this on `2.3.x`

issue.title: Assets controller blows up on request to /assets/stylesheets

repository.name: playframework
repository.description: The Community Maintained High Velocity Web Framework For Java and Scala.

issue.body:
Assuming a routes definition like:

```
GET     /assets/*file               controllers.Assets.at(path="/public", file)
```

If I request `/assets/foo` or `/assets/stylesheets/bar`, I get a `404` as expected,  However, accessing `/assets/stylesheets` results in a `500` response with the following logged:

```
! @6m8bn5ei8 - Internal server error, for (GET) [/assets/stylesheets] ->

play.api.Application$$anon$1: Execution exception[[RuntimeException: Unexpected error while serving stylesheets at /public: null]]
    at play.api.Application$class.handleError(Application.scala:296) ~[com.typesafe.play.play_2.10-2.3.8.jar:2.3.8]
    at play.api.DefaultApplication.handleError(Application.scala:402) [com.typesafe.play.play_2.10-2.3.8.jar:2.3.8]
    at play.core.server.netty.PlayDefaultUpstreamHandler$$anonfun$3$$anonfun$applyOrElse$4.apply(PlayDefaultUpstreamHandler.scala:320) [com.typesafe.play.play_2.10-2.3.8.jar:2.3.8]
    at play.core.server.netty.PlayDefaultUpstreamHandler$$anonfun$3$$anonfun$applyOrElse$4.apply(PlayDefaultUpstreamHandler.scala:320) [com.typesafe.play.play_2.10-2.3.8.jar:2.3.8]
    at scala.Option.map(Option.scala:145) [org.scala-lang.scala-library-2.10.4.jar:na]
Caused by: java.lang.RuntimeException: Unexpected error while serving stylesheets at /public: null
    at controllers.AssetsBuilder$$anonfun$at$1$$anonfun$apply$1.applyOrElse(Assets.scala:432) ~[com.typesafe.play.play_2.10-2.3.8.jar:8aae6734e371eeb215085b1bd35fc225ff5f7485]
    at controllers.AssetsBuilder$$anonfun$at$1$$anonfun$apply$1.applyOrElse(Assets.scala:425) ~[com.typesafe.play.play_2.10-2.3.8.jar:8aae6734e371eeb215085b1bd35fc225ff5f7485]
    at scala.concurrent.Future$$anonfun$recoverWith$1.apply(Future.scala:344) [org.scala-lang.scala-library-2.10.4.jar:na]
    at scala.concurrent.Future$$anonfun$recoverWith$1.apply(Future.scala:343) [org.scala-lang.scala-library-2.10.4.jar:na]
    at scala.concurrent.impl.CallbackRunnable.run(Promise.scala:32) [org.scala-lang.scala-library-2.10.4.jar:na]
Caused by: java.lang.NullPointerException: null
    at java.io.FilterInputStream.close(FilterInputStream.java:181) ~[na:1.7.0_06]
    at sun.net.www.protocol.jar.JarURLConnection$JarURLInputStream.close(JarURLConnection.java:108) ~[na:1.7.0_06]
    at controllers.AssetInfo$$anonfun$4.apply(Assets.scala:149) ~[com.typesafe.play.play_2.10-2.3.8.jar:8aae6734e371eeb215085b1bd35fc225ff5f7485]
    at controllers.AssetInfo$$anonfun$4.apply(Assets.scala:144) ~[com.typesafe.play.play_2.10-2.3.8.jar:8aae6734e371eeb215085b1bd35fc225ff5f7485]
    at scala.Option.map(Option.scala:145) [org.scala-lang.scala-library-2.10.4.jar:na]
```

The same is true for `/assets/images` and `/assets/javascripts`.
